pkgapi 0.0.1
  • Reference

NA

Things to do

  • Error if body is provided on an endpoint that does not want one (pkgapi_input_validator_body)

Things to note

One disadvantage of the current approach is that typed dynamic routes are pretty clunky - one must use the plumber version and if a typemismatch occurs we get a 404 not a 400.

Things to create tickets for

State not yet handled, but will be done the same way

Things from headers still not accepted as an argument, but will be handled much the same way

Things from cookies still not accepted

No easy way yet of querying metadata about what an endpoint takes (will be needed to set the swagger)

Allow duplicated query parameters to be a vector. This is actually slightly subtle because we need a nice way of communicating to pkgapi users that it’s a vector and also out to swagger, but that’s not obvious and might be easier after we start on swagger support.

Allow varied type inputs (e.g. application/octet-stream and application/json)

Only allow post to be provided for endpoints that allow it (GET should not for example)

Allow querying of input metadata from then handler (currently not allowed by the behaviour of pkgapi_inputs_init) - we at least are interested to know if things are required or not

The request interface should set appriate header types - doing this time as we deal with the accept header seems a good idea.

Mime subtype handling is not done (practically an encoding issue for text/plain and little else)

The pkgapi_validator function should check that we have valid json even if no schema is provided

Variadic queries (swich on presence of … in function)

If a filter throws an error, the return value gets serialised twice and it looks terrible

404 errors are not in our standardised style

Cope with Accept: headers in request (this should come for free when we do the header inputs)

Handle method on just the endpoint, rather than having to create a whole api for it - no reason why this can’t be done. We’ll need to be clever about how the path parts are dealt with.

Developed by Rich FitzJohn.
